Snippet:
Model Monitoring_004
Fiddler detects feature drifts in your production environment and it displays the drift on its UI over a period of time. This makes it very easy for users to see when the feature drift has started. You can configure Fiddler to generate an alert when the feature drift starts. Fiddler can also be used as a diagnosis tool to understand "why" the drift is happening. So not only can it let the users know "when" the feature drift starts, but it can help you understand "why" that drift is happening. You can find more details about this here - https://docs.fiddler.ai/pages/user-guide/data-science-concepts/monitoring/data-drift/​
Question: Model Monitoring_004
Answer_Answer: Fiddler detects feature drifts in your production environment and it displays the drift on its UI over a period of time. This makes it very easy for users to see when the feature drift has started. You can configure Fiddler to generate an alert when the feature drift starts. Fiddler can also be used as a diagnosis tool to understand "why" the drift is happening. So not only can it let the users know "when" the feature drift starts, but it can help you understand "why" that drift is happening. You can find more details about this here - https://docs.fiddler.ai/pages/user-guide/data-science-concepts/monitoring/data-drift/​
Section Name: Ability to detect drift at feature level (e.g. feature distribution drift detection)

Snippet:
Model Monitoring_003
One of the consistent feedback that we receive from our customers is the ease of use of the Fiddler UI. One of the strength of Fiddler is the way we bring in monitoring and explainability together. The UI provides a seamless way of diagnosing a model performance problem and finding the root cause of it. Fiddler will alert the user on "what" is happening within your models. But it also helps in finding out "why" that happened. And the way the UI is built, you could get to the "why it happened" with a 10-20 minute analysis using Fiddler. This is how you can reduce your MTTR to identify and resolve model performance issues within a small time.
Question: Model Monitoring_003
Answer_Answer: One of the consistent feedback that we receive from our customers is the ease of use of the Fiddler UI. One of the strength of Fiddler is the way we bring in monitoring and explainability together. The UI provides a seamless way of diagnosing a model performance problem and finding the root cause of it. Fiddler will alert the user on "what" is happening within your models. But it also helps in finding out "why" that happened. And the way the UI is built, you could get to the "why it happened" with a 10-20 minute analysis using Fiddler. This is how you can reduce your MTTR to identify and resolve model performance issues within a small time.

Snippet:
Model Monitoring_001
Fiddler has extensive capabilities to perform analytics on the model metrics that have been captured by the tool. You can slice and dice on both your baseline dataset and also your production dataset. You can also get out-of-the-box dashboards that shows different charts like precision-recall, ROC chart, calibration chart, PDP plots etc. Fiddler provides a SQL like interface where you can create your own queries to visualize  the data and perform detailed analysis on. You can find further details on the analytics capability within Fiddler here - https://docs.fiddler.ai/pages/user-guide/data-science-concepts/analytics/​
Question: Model Monitoring_001

You can find further details on the analytics capability within Fiddler here - https://docs.fiddler.ai/pages/user-guide/data-science-concepts/analytics/​

Snippet:
Alerting_004
The following types of alert triggers are present in Fiddler. Performance alerts, Data drift alerts, Service health alerts and Data integrity alerts (https://docs.fiddler.ai/pages/user-guide/data-science-concepts/monitoring/alerts/​). Fiddler allows you to generate an email notification when one of the alert condition is satisfied. Fiddler also supports integrating with PagerDuty. You can find more information about these here - https://docs.fiddler.ai/pages/user-guide/data-science-concepts/monitoring/alerts/#email-alert​ and  https://docs.fiddler.ai/pages/integrations/pagerduty/​

Fiddler allows you to generate an email notification when one of the alert condition is satisfied. Fiddler also supports integrating with PagerDuty. You can find more information about these here - https://docs.fiddler.ai/pages/user-guide/data-science-concepts/monitoring/alerts/#email-alert​ and  https://docs.fiddler.ai/pages/integrations/pagerduty/​

Answer_Answer: Fiddler detects data outliers and shows them as "Out of Range" violations. These are displayed on the Fiddler UI against the production data. Further details can be found here: ​https://docs.fiddler.ai/pages/user-guide/data-science-concepts/monitoring/data-integrity/​

Snippet:
Data Input_002
Fiddler detects the following three types of data integrity issues: Type violation, Range violation and missing value violations. These violations are detected in real time on the production data and displayed over a time period. It helps a user easily identify when and what type of data integrity issues are happening in production. You can find more details about this here - https://docs.fiddler.ai/pages/user-guide/data-science-concepts/monitoring/data-integrity/​
Question: Data Input_002
Answer_Answer: Fiddler detects the following three types of data integrity issues: Type violation, Range violation and missing value violations. These violations are detected in real time on the production data and displayed over a time period. It helps a user easily identify when and what type of data integrity issues are happening in production. You can find more details about this here - https://docs.fiddler.ai/pages/user-guide/data-science-concepts/monitoring/data-integrity/​

Snippet:
Data Input_001
Fiddler detects data drift between the data in the production environment and a baseline training dataset. It displays this information over a historical time period so that the user can see when the data drift started happening. And data drift can be plotted for every feature input for that model. You can find further information about this here - https://docs.fiddler.ai/pages/user-guide/data-science-concepts/monitoring/data-drift/​
Question: Data Input_001
Answer_Answer: Fiddler detects data drift between the data in the production environment and a baseline training dataset. It displays this information over a historical time period so that the user can see when the data drift started happening. And data drift can be plotted for every feature input for that model. You can find further information about this here - https://docs.fiddler.ai/pages/user-guide/data-science-concepts/monitoring/data-drift/​

What is the organization structure? How many employees are there? Where are they located?
Fiddler currently has ~45 FTE employees across all areas (Engineering, Data Science, GTM). Fiddler's company headquarters are in Palo Alto, CA with some remote locations in the United States, and a small team in Bangalore, India. Fiddler is a private corporation (incorporated in Delaware), backed by investors that include: Lightspeed Ventures, Lux Capital, Insight Ventures, Bloomberg Beta, Amazon Alexa Fund, Lockheed Martin, and In-Q-Tel. Snippet:
What architecture and technology standards, policies and procedures are followed and complied with?
Fiddler follows a layer architecture frame work that consists of following stacks - Business, Data, Application, Technology. The information flows in the form of requirement from Business >> Data >> Application >> Technology. We have defined policies, procedures, processes, training and tools around each of the domain frameworks. These get validated as part of our annual SOC2 Type 2 audit performed by external audit firm.

Snippet:
What are the vendor and client roles and responsibilities within this solution (RACI)?
Fiddler (vendor) hosting the customer on their managed cloud handles VPC cluster creation, management and providing the necessary scale to meet the customer needs. Fiddler provides highly available, scalable solution and protects customer data in transit and at rest and protect the clusters from vulnerabilities and provides a secure access.

Client anonymizes any proprietary and PII data before sending it to Fiddler. Control user access to Fiddler through SSO by integrating Fiddler with their identity provider.
Question: What are the vendor and client roles and responsibilities within this solution (RACI)?
Answer_Response:
Fiddler (vendor) hosting the customer on their managed cloud handles VPC cluster creation, management and providing the necessary scale to meet the customer needs. Fiddler provides highly available, scalable solution and protects customer data in transit and at rest and protect the clusters from vulnerabilities and provides a secure access.

Client anonymizes any proprietary and PII data before sending it to Fiddler. Control user access to Fiddler through SSO by integrating Fiddler with their identity provider.

Snippet:
Please describe the software development life cycle?  How often are new releases created, tested and deployed?
Following are the 5 main stages of Fiddler SDLC - Design, Code Review, Testing, Launch Review and Release


Fiddler ensures that developed code is secure and follows best practices like static analysis of code, vulnerability scanners etc, rigorous design and code reviews, security training, secure coding guidelines. Fiddler will maintain broadly two kinds of releases (STS, or LTS)

• STS (Short-term support) Release - 6 to 8 weeks -> demo, cloud customers
• LTS (Long-term support) Release - One every 6 months -> on-prem customers
Question: Please describe the software development life cycle?  How often are new releases created, tested and deployed?
Answer_Response:
Following are the 5 main stages of Fiddler SDLC - Design, Code Review, Testing, Launch Review and Release


Fiddler ensures that developed code is secure and follows best practices like static analysis of code, vulnerability scanners etc, rigorous design and code reviews, security training, secure coding guidelines. Fiddler will maintain broadly two kinds of releases (STS, or LTS)

• STS (Short-term support) Release - 6 to 8 weeks -> demo, cloud customers
• LTS (Long-term support) Release - One every 6 months -> on-prem customers

Snippet:
If there is web service integration, how are web services secured and authenticated?
Fiddler Application generates Auth token which API uses and gets authenticated before traffic enters into Fiddler. Fiddler also has user login and password authentication before the user can access Fiddler. Fiddler can provide SSO by integration with customer identity provider. We encrypt all requests and responses using SSL/TLS.
Question: If there is web service integration, how are web services secured and authenticated?
Answer_Response: Fiddler Application generates Auth token which API uses and gets authenticated before traffic enters into Fiddler. Fiddler also has user login and password authentication before the user can access Fiddler. Fiddler can provide SSO by integration with customer identity provider. We encrypt all requests and responses using SSL/TLS.
Section Name: Planning & Operations - Security - Data Access, Synchronization, Isolation, Encryption, Operations & Identity Management

Snippet:
What are the data integration design elements ( file transfer, APIs, web services, direct connection, proprietary protocol, browser, etc )?
Customer uses Fiddler Client SDK APIs to upload data, models and production traffic into Fiddler. Fiddler provides prediction, explanation and model performance insights through the web application running on the browser. All in-transit data are encrypted using SSL/TLS encryption mechanism.
Question: What are the data integration design elements ( file transfer, APIs, web services, direct connection, proprietary protocol, browser, etc )?
Answer_Response: Customer uses Fiddler Client SDK APIs to upload data, models and production traffic into Fiddler. Fiddler provides prediction, explanation and model performance insights through the web application running on the browser. All in-transit data are encrypted using SSL/TLS encryption mechanism.

Snippet:
Can a high level description of the network, network security isolation designs and client connectivity requirements be shared?
Yes, we can share this if needed.

All customer VPCs are hosted in a separate AWS prod account. Within that, each customer is hosted on a separate VPC. This VPC provides the secure, logical isolated system. We will provide customer with a unique URL to access Fiddler web application and SDK for API access.

Snippet:
Are there data archiving capabilities within the solution?  Is this configurable?  Are there environment or customer limits?
Fiddler stores customer data on AWS RDS and S3. These AWS services provide data archiving capabilities and we backup the data on a nightly basis. Default backup is 30 days and this is configurable if customer needs to extend the storage.
Question: Are there data archiving capabilities within the solution?  Is this configurable?  Are there environment or customer limits?
Answer_Response: Fiddler stores customer data on AWS RDS and S3. These AWS services provide data archiving capabilities and we backup the data on a nightly basis. Default backup is 30 days and this is configurable if customer needs to extend the storage.
Section Name: Technology - Hosting Provider, Data Location, High Level Architecture

Answer_Additional Comments: Fiddler does not have formal PIA process. However, that being said Fiddler treats our customer data seriously and have some security practices in the process of sending, receiving, storing, access controls, and deletion data. Fiddler uses industry standard crypto algo to protect data in transit and at rest. Similarly, Fiddler has separate production environments to host our customer systems and restricts employees access to this environment. Our current SOC2 type2 review is focused on Security, Confidentiality and Availability pillars. In the future, we are looking to include Privacy too.
